items.heading: Should AI in Education Focus on Tools or Understanding?
items.summary: The text discusses using SPIKE Prime to teach AI learning processes without new hardware. Students engage with a catapult-style robot to understand AI through feedback and iteration.
items.text: The recent announcement of LEGO Education‚Äôs Computer Science & AI sets raises an important question: should AI in robotics education focus on using AI tools, or on understanding how learning algorithms actually work?  Understanding how AI learns ‚Äî through feedback, adaptation, and iteration ‚Äî can already be taught today, even with robotics sets that many schools already have in their classrooms.  One example is Launcher AI+, an advanced SPIKE Prime activity developed by the RoboCamp team.  Students build a catapult-style robot that repeatedly launches a ball toward a target. After each attempt, the robot receives feedback ‚Äî the shot was too short or too far ‚Äî and adjusts its launch power accordingly. With every iteration, the program updates its parameters and gradually improves accuracy.  There is no black-box AI here. Students design the learning logic themselves and can clearly see how data and feedback shape the robot‚Äôs behavior over time.  This is what learning about AI can look like ‚Äî without new hardware, and without using AI as a shortcut instead of understanding how it works.  If you‚Äôd like to learn more about this approach, you‚Äôll find additional details in the comments below.  #robocamp #LEGOEducation #SPIKEprime #STEM #STEMEducation #stemforkids #edtech #AIinEducation #machinelearningeducation

items.heading: SPIKE Prime and Essential Availability Extended
items.summary: LEGO Education announced a new AI product line and extended support for SPIKE Prime and Essential, which will be available until 2026 with software support until 2031.
items.text: LEGO¬Æ Education has announced a new Computer Science & AI product line and, at the same time, shared an update regarding the retirement of SPIKE Prime and SPIKE Essential.  For schools already working with SPIKE sets, the following confirmed timelines are particularly important: ‚Äì SPIKE Prime and SPIKE Essential will remain available for purchase at least until mid-2026, ‚Äì spare parts for SPIKE Prime and SPIKE Essential will be available until June 2028, ‚Äì software for SPIKE will remain supported until June 2031.  This means that the well-established SPIKE Prime and SPIKE Essential sets will continue to be reliable, long-term educational tools for many years to come.  As for the new Computer Science & AI sets ‚Äî at this stage, it is simply too early to evaluate them. We don‚Äôt form opinions until we have had the opportunity to work hands-on with the sets and test them in real classroom conditions.  We will publish a full review of the new sets after proper testing.  In the meantime, we invite you to read our review of LEGO Education Science. Since the new Computer Science & AI line is based on the same generation of electronic components, it is currently the best available reference point for understanding the direction LEGO Education is heading with its future educational products.  Link to the review in the comments.  #robocamp #LEGOEducation #SPIKEprime #SPIKEEssential #educationalrobotics #STEM #stemeducation #stemforkids #edtech

items.heading: 3D Printing in Robotics: Potential and Challenges
items.summary: The post considers the potential and challenges of using 3D printing in SPIKE Prime robotics education, weighing creative freedom against logistical issues.
items.text: üöÄ 3D Printing for Robotics ‚Äì Unlimited Potential or Unnecessary Complication?  At RoboCamp, you'll find lesson plans that incorporate 3D-printed components, specifically designed to unlock the full potential of LEGO¬Æ Education SPIKE‚Ñ¢ Prime.  ‚úÖ On one hand ‚Äì unlimited creative freedom! Design and print exactly what you need. The only limit is your imagination!  ‚ö†Ô∏è On the other hand ‚Äì logistical challenges. You need access to a 3D printer and must allocate time for printing, which doesn't always go smoothly.  ‚û°Ô∏è What do you think? Would you utilize a 3D printer in this way? Is it a fantastic method to enhance robotics classes, or is it too much trouble?  üí¨ Share your thoughts ‚Äì your opinions are invaluable to us!

items.heading: Learn Python by Building Classic Games with SPIKE Prime
items.summary: Students use SPIKE Prime to learn Python and game mechanics by building classic games like Snake and Arkanoid, as part of an expert-level course.
items.text: Snake and Arkanoid in Python? Build them yourself with SPIKE Prime! ü§ñüïπÔ∏è   Remember playing Snake on your first mobile phone? Or spending hours with Arkanoid on an old computer? For many of us, these games were our very first step into the digital world ‚Äì first as players, then as programmers, and today as educators.  At RoboCamp, we now give kids the chance to experience something similar. Only this time ‚Äî from the other side of the screen.  As part of our SPIKE Prime Programming Course Expert, students create their own versions of these classic games using LEGO kits and the Python programming language.üîßüß†üíª  It‚Äôs not just fun. It‚Äôs: ‚úÖ hands-on coding in Python, ‚úÖ learning how game mechanics work, ‚úÖ exploring the history of gamedev through experience.  Why do we teach kids to program Snake and Arkanoid? Because that‚Äôs how our own tech journey began. Those pixelated games sparked our curiosity and made us ask: How does it work? Could I build this myself?  Now it‚Äôs the kids‚Äô turn. We give them the tools ‚Äî and they become the creators. Python. Robots. The classics of gamedev. All ready ‚Äî in our expert-level course.  Join us on this journey from pixels to robots! üíæ‚û°Ô∏èü§ñ  #RoboCamp #LEGOEducation #SPIKEPrime #PythonForKids #EducationalRobotics #STEMEducation

items.text:
Build Snake & Arkanoid with SPIKE Prime? Yes, in Python! ü§ñ üïπÔ∏è

Our journey into tech started with simple games.
Snake on our first phones. Arkanoid on an old computer.

In our SPIKE Prime Programming Course Expert, students:

items.heading: Measure Wind Speed with 3D-Printed Anemometer and SPIKE Prime
items.summary: Students use SPIKE Prime and a 3D-printed propeller to build an anemometer, integrating STEM education with real-world data collection.
items.text:
üå¨Ô∏è What is wind ‚Äî and how can we measure its strength with LEGO¬Æ?

In this lesson plan, students build a fully functional anemometer using LEGO¬Æ Education SPIKE‚Ñ¢ Prime and a custom 3D-printed propeller. It‚Äôs a perfect way to combine STEM learning, engineering and real-world data collection ‚Äî all in one engaging class. üìäüí°

Here‚Äôs what the lesson includes:
1Ô∏è‚É£ A propeller designed from scratch in Autodesk Tinkercad,
